elements.content: Coordinative networks containing lanthanide ions attached via phosphonate ester functionalities provide remarkable luminescence properties. On the basis of ditopic phosphonic ester ligands with biphenylene and 9,10-anthracenylene bridges, a series of compounds with formal composition {[M­(NO3)3]­L} n or {[M­(NO3)3]2(L1)3} n (L = C28H40O6P2; L1 = C26H40O6P2) with M = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu, and Y have been synthesized, structurally characterized, and the luminescence behavior was explored in the visible and NIR spectral regions, where applicable. In contrast to closely related networks based on biphenyl bisphosphonate esters from previous work, no evidence for ligand-to-metal energy transfer could be observed, despite strong near-infrared emission in some cases. Unique behavior is found for the Eu derivative with the 9,10-anthracenylene bridge, which is nonemissive, showing neither ligand- nor metal-based emission.

In contrast to closely related networks based on biphenyl bisphosphonate esters from previous work, no evidence for ligand-to-metal energy transfer could be observed, despite strong near-infrared emission in some cases. Unique behavior is found for the Eu derivative with the 9,10-anthracenylene bridge, which is nonemissive, showing neither ligand- nor metal-based emission.

elements.content: Coordinative networks with ditopic phosphonate ester ligands have been prepared and structurally characterized for the entire series of lanthanides showing unexpected luminescence behavior in the UV-visible and near infrared spectral range, including a non-emissive europium derivative.

Lanthanide-based coordination polymers are especially attractive owing to their large and flexible coordination sphere and their luminescence properties, which furnished unique applications as for instance in anticounterfeiting. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Supramolecular structures such as metal-organic frameworks or coordination polymers have gained outstanding attention due to their tailor-made properties such as porosity, magnetism, and luminescence. Lanthanide-based coordination polymers are especially attractive owing to their large and flexible coordination sphere and their luminescence properties, which furnished unique applications as for instance in anticounterfeiting. In previous works, phosphonate ester ligands have been employed to replace carboxylic acids. Phosphonate esters provide a very rigid structure, which can improve various properties of coordination polymers evolving around their photophysical properties. In particular, a pronounced antenna effect and attractive quantum yields have been obtained with biphenyl bridged bisphosphonate esters carrying isopropoxy groups.

elements.content: Interestingly, the structural features were nearly independent of the metal center employed. To further develop this strategy, we wanted to complete the series of lanthanide complexes for this successful biphenyl-based ligand and, moreover, replace the torsionally flexible biphenyl backbone of ligand A with a more rigid and fluorescent 9,10-anthracenediyl bridging unit such as in B, which in turn is less congested than durene-based ligand C that was previously described as ethoxy derivative (). In fact, such aryl-based bisphosphonic acid ester ligands are quite rare, despite the fact that such compounds have been synthesized for other purposes, albeit with a limited characterization.

In fact, such aryl-based bisphosphonic acid ester ligands are quite rare, despite the fact that such compounds have been synthesized for other purposes, albeit with a limited characterization.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially obtained from Sigma-Aldrich or TCI and used without additional purification. NMR measurements were performed on Varian 400 MHz and 500 MHz spectrometers. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ATR IR spectrometer with a diamond probe. The microwave-assisted syntheses were carried out in pyrex vessels closed with Activent lids using a CEM DISCOVER-SP reactor. Excitation and emission spectra as well as luminescent quantum yield (absolute method) measurements for the range 200–950 nm were acquired on a Hamamatsu C11347 system. The program ORIGIN 2017 was used for handling and analysis of spectral data.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All reagents and solvents were commercially obtained from Sigma-Aldrich or TCI and used without additional purification. NMR measurements were performed on Varian 400 MHz and 500 MHz spectrometers. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker ATR IR spectrometer with a diamond probe. The microwave-assisted syntheses were carried out in pyrex vessels closed with Activent lids using a CEM DISCOVER-SP reactor. Excitation and emission spectra as well as luminescent quantum yield (absolute method) measurements for the range 200-950 nm were acquired on a Hamamatsu C11347 system. The program ORIGIN 2017 was used for handling and analysis of spectral data.

elements.content: NIR solid-state excitation and emission spectra were measured with a Fluorolog III spectrometer (Horiba Jobin-Yvon); the samples were irradiated by a 450 W Xe lamp, and the luminescent photons were detected by a Hamamatsu photomultiplier in the visible range (190–860 nm) and by a liquid-nitrogen-cooled InGaAs photodiode in the infrared range (800–1800 nm). The solid-state samples were put in a quartz cell in an Oxford Instruments Optistat CF cryostat for both ambient and low-temperature measurements. The excitation and emission slits were fixed at 5 nm in the infrared range and 2 nm in the visible range, the integration time was 100 ms, and the step size was 1 nm.

The solid-state samples were put in a quartz cell in an Oxford Instruments Optistat CF cryostat for both ambient and low-temperature measurements. The excitation and emission slits were fixed at 5 nm in the infrared range and 2 nm in the visible range, the integration time was 100 ms, and the step size was 1 nm.

elements.content: Combustion analyses were performed using a HEKAtech Euro EA 3000 elemental analyzer. For the analyses, samples were prepared in tin cups with V2O5 as an additive to ensure complete combustion. X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on either STOE IPDS 2 with an image plate (diameter 34 cm) using a Mo-GENIX source (λ = 0.71073 nm) or STOE StadiVari with DECTRIS PILATUS 200 K using a Mo-GENIX source (λ = 0.71073 nm). All structures were solved using the dual space method (SHELXT) and were refined against F2 with SHELXL-2018/3. All non-hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. The hydrogen atoms were placed on neighboring atoms using a riding model. Additional programs used for structural analysis include WinGX, Mercury, and Platon. The structure of 7 contains a disordered molecule of solvent (methanol), which could not be resolved, and moreover is limited by poor crystal quality owing to partial solvent loss. In the structures of L1-based compounds 16–20, 22, 23, 26, 28, and 29, substantial disorder of the isopropyl units could not be resolved. However, all polymers 16–30 are isostructural, showing similar cell constants, and the salient features of the disordered structures are in perfect agreement with those of the structures in this series showing no disorder. Details of the structure determinations and refinement for L, 1–20, 22, and 25–29 are summarized in Tables S3–S7 of the Supporting Information.

elements.content: In a microwave flask, 1.6 g (5.2 mmol) of 9,10-bis­(chloromethyl)­anthracene was placed together with 10 mL (57 mmol) of triisopropyl phosphite. The resulting mixture was heated for 1 h at 180 °C (200 W) in a microwave reactor under autogenous pressure (10 bar). Upon cooling to 20 °C, the flask was vented for 10 min to ensure degassing. The resulting yellow solid was dissolved in 50 mL of isopropanol and filtered. The isopropanol was removed at reduced pressure, and the resulting solid was washed with 100 mL of cold water and dried overnight, giving 2.8 g of yellow crystalline product with 90% yield referring to the starting material 9,10-bis­(chloromethyl)­anthracene.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of 9,10-Bis(dimethylphosphorylisopropyl) Anthracene (L)

In a microwave flask, 1.6 g (5.2 mmol) of 9,10-bis(chloromethyl)anthracene was placed together with 10 mL (57 mmol) of triisopropyl phosphite. The resulting mixture was heated for 1 h at 180 °C (200 W) in a microwave reactor under autogenous pressure (10 bar). Upon cooling to 20 °C, the flask was vented for 10 min to ensure degassing. The resulting yellow solid was dissolved in 50 mL of isopropanol and filtered. The isopropanol was removed at reduced pressure, and the resulting solid was washed with 100 mL of cold water and dried overnight, giving 2.8 g of yellow crystalline product with 90% yield referring to the starting material 9,10-bis(chloromethyl)anthracene.

Synthesis of Lanthanide­(III) Coordination Polymers (<bold>1</bold>–<bold>15</bold>)

The ligand L (120 mg, 0.22 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of methanol. To this solution, Ln­(NO3)3·xH2O (0.22 mmol) dissolved in the same solvent was added with vigorous stirring at room temperature. By slow evaporation of the solvent, compounds 1–15 were collected as a pale yellow crystalline material after filtration from the mother liquor.

elements.content: The solid-state structure of ligand L was determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The crystal cell (space group P1̅) contains two symmetrically independent molecules of identical composition. Both molecules contain planar anthracene units with phosphonate moieties on opposite sides of the anthracene plane. The main difference of both molecules is the orientation of the PO units. In one molecule, the PO vectors are pointing in opposite directions, forming a transoid structure (a). The other molecule in the unit has similar directional vectors, for the PO bond forming a cisoid arrangement (b). The formal PO bond lengths are 1.4616(14), 1.4630(14), and 1.4654(14) Å with no deviation from standard bond lengths for similar compounds. The formal P–O single bonds are in the range of 1.5703(13)–1.5811(13) Å with no large deviation from similar compounds.

elements.content: Complexation of Ln3+ with ligand L can be accomplished in solution by increasing the concentrations of both components via evaporation of the solvent. Following identical procedures starting from Ln­(NO3)3·xH2O, one-dimensional coordination polymers were obtained that occur in three different structural motifs for which the motif adopted depends on the nature of the metal center. Lanthanum forms a type I motif (), whereas cerium, praseodymium, neodymium, samarium, holmium, and erbium adopt type II (). The rest of the lanthanides (Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Tm, Yb, Lu) and yttrium form the type III motif (). Since there are only marginal deviations within each structural motif, only one example of each representative will be discussed. In the asymmetric unit (space group P1̅) of the lanthanum polymer (type I), a lanthanum nitrate core is present with two halves of ligand and one molecule of water and methanol, adding up to a coordination number of 10 at the metal. Two anthracene units are slightly twisted from each other with an interplanar angle of 13.8°. The La­(NO3)3 unit has no large deviation in La–O bonds compared to similar compounds. The lanthanum oxygen bond belonging to the phosphonate unit, 2.4554(18) Å, is similar to the one in other coordination polymers involving phosphonate ligands. The two polymer strands are connected to each other via hydrogen bonds ().

elements.content: The separation between donor and acceptor for these hydrogen bonds is 2.817(2) and 2.914(3) Å with almost linear angles of 156(4) and 171(3)° (Table S1). These data suggest medium-strong hydrogen bonds according to the classification of Steiner. Polymers 2–5 and 10–11 featuring motif II were obtained in the same way as polymer 1, namely, by slow evaporation of a mixture of Ln­(NO3)3·xH2O (Ln = Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Ho, Er) and ligand L in methanol. The samarium-based polymer will be described as representative for the type II motif. The asymmetric unit (space group P1̅) contains a Sm­(NO3)3 core coordinated by two halves of symmetrically independent ligand and one molecule of water () adding up to a coordination number of 9 at samarium. The two anthracene units show a much larger interplanar angle (66.6°) than in the type I polymer. The one-dimensional chains of the polymer are interconnected with neighboring chains via hydrogen bonds, the details of which are given in the Supporting Information (Table S2).

elements.content: As compared to the type I polymer, where both hydrogen bonds connect the same polymer chain, in type II the hydrogen bonds interconnect two different chains forming a more complex packing. The absence of noncoordinating solvent molecules enables π–π stacking between symmetrically connected anthracene units in a displaced fashion with an interplanar distance of 3.3 Å and an intercentroid distance of 4.6 Å. The donor–acceptor distances for two hydrogen bonds are 2.822(2) and 2.845(3) Å with linear angles of 168(4) and 166(3)° (Table S2). These values classify the hydrogen bonds as medium strong and show that hydrogen bonds impact the packing of this polymer. The Sm­(NO3)3 core shows no significant deviation in bond lengths compared to other samarium-based coordination polymers. As in polymer 1, the PO bond and the angles around the phosphorus atom show no large deviation from standard values either for free phosphonates or for coordination polymers.

elements.content: The rest of the lanthanide metals (Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Tm, Yb, Lu) and yttrium form the type III polymer motif for which the europium polymer will be described as representative example. Again, the repeating unit (space group P21/c) consists of one ligand coordinated to a Eu­(NO3)3 core along with a molecule of methanol () adding up to a coordination number of 9 at the metal. Owing to disorder of noncoordinated methanol, there are no discrete hydrogen bonds connecting neighboring chains as in the other two motifs I and II. The Eu­(NO3)3 core as well as the tetrahedrally coordinated phosphorus atom shows no peculiarities in geometry compared with related complexes. The anthracene subunit is slightly bent, deviating from planarity with an RMS of 0.0439, which corresponds to a distance of 0.125 Å for the atoms of the outer rings with respect to the central ring plane. Within the isostructural series forming the type III polymer motif, the cell volumes are very similar, with Eu-based 6 showing the largest (3950.2(2) Å3) and Gd-based 7 showing the smallest (3910.4(3) Å3) cell volume.

elements.content: For comparison, a series of closely related lanthanide complexes with the more flexible biphenyl bridged bisphosphonate isopropoxy ester has been prepared. Apart from the corresponding Eu-, Tb-, Dy-, and Y-based coordination polymers, which had been reported before, these compounds have not been described so far. Coordination polymers 16–30 are formed in solution from the respective Ln­(NO3)3 salt and an excess of ligand L1 by slowly evaporating the solvent at 20 °C (). From the solvents tested, ethanol was advantageous to obtain single crystals that were suitable for X-ray diffraction, whereas other alcohols resulted in the formation of microcrystalline material.

elements.content: Polymers 16–30 are all isostructural featuring one-dimensional zigzag motifs, which are arranged in two-dimensional (2D) sheets (). The resulting sheets are packed in the form of alternating AB stacks. Interestingly, no evidence for π–π stacking of neighboring biphenyl rings is found probably owing to the perpendicular orientation of adjacent phenyl rings.

elements.content: As representative structure out of the series of polymers 16–30, Gd-based compound 22 will be discussed in more detail. The latter crystallizes in space group P21/n. Within the asymmetric unit, 1.5 molecules of ligand L1 and one unit of Gd­(NO3)3 are present, resulting in a formal composition of [[Gd­(NO3)­3]2L3]. This ratio is further corroborated by combustion analysis. The solid-state structure reveals coordination of each gadolinium ion by three bidentate nitrate anions and three monodentate ligands, resulting in a coordination number of 9 for the metal ion ().

elements.content: The bond distances between gadolinium and the nitrate oxygen atoms cover a range between 2.445(3) and 2.503(3) Å, which is common for related nitrate complexes. By contrast, the Gd–O distances related to the phosphonic ester ligands range between 2.326(3) and 2.344(2) Å, being slightly shorter than those related to the nitrate (v.s.). The structure of Eu-based congener 21 has been previously reported and shows a reduced cell volume (by ca. 200 Å3) as compared to its Tb, Dy, and Y analogs. The same holds true for comparing 21 with the structures of the series 16–30 reported here for the first time, where the cell volume of Eu-based 21 (4680.8(4) Å3) again is significantly lower than for all other polymers of this series. For the latter, values range from 4815.4(3) to 4900.05(18) Å3 with Yb-based 28 at the lower limit and La-based 16 at the higher limit of this range. These findings for Eu-based complex 21 are in sharp contrast to Eu complex 6 obtained for the anthracene-based ligand L, for which an increased cell volume had been found (v.s.).

elements.content: All coordination polymers 1–30 are insoluble in common solvents. Exposure of the L- and L1-based polymers 1–30 to dichloromethane causes polymers to swell and decompose after a short time. Therefore, multinuclear NMR data could be acquired for the free ligands L and L1 only. Besides single-crystal X-ray diffraction, compounds 1–30 were all characterized by combustion analysis and IR spectroscopy. The infrared spectra show significant shifts of the characteristic PO vibrational band in coordination polymers 1–15, ranging from 1155 to 1169 cm–1 (depending on the central metal), compared with the free ligand L (1239 cm–1), whereas the L1-based polymers 16–30 show bands in a more narrow range of 1161–1166 cm–1 for the coordinated ligand again shifted to lower energies compared to noncoordinated L1 (1232 cm–1). Similarly, the P–O vibrational band in coordination polymers 1–15, covering a range from 1094 to 1097 cm–1, resonates at lower energies compared with the free ligand L (1108 cm–1). The corresponding P–O band for L1 (1105 cm–1) is shifted to lower energies in compounds 16–30 as well (1097–1099 cm–1).

elements.content: Solid-state photoluminescence of ligand L shows a strong absorption in the UV range with an absorption maximum at 378 nm and an emission maximum at 471 nm with a quantum yield of 11% (). This contrasts the photophysical characteristics of L1, which is characterized by an emission quantum yield of 89% in the solid state according to an earlier work, where an emission maximum at 410 nm is observed for excitation at 350 nm. Most lanthanide ions are good emitters in either the visible or the infrared spectral region. Investigation of the luminescence properties of the above-mentioned coordination polymers did not reveal any ligand-to-metal energy transfer for the lanthanides prone to emission in the visible spectral region. In turn, modified ligand emission is observed where three (5 and 9) or two (8) new broad emission bands are observed instead of one ().

elements.content: These findings would be in agreement with almost equal energy levels for the ligand and lanthanide emissions with preferred ligand-centered emission. Similar observations of exclusive ligand emission have been made by Vittal et al. using a carboxylate-based anthracene ligand. In marked contrast to previous results, Eu-based polymer 6 shows no emission at all, neither ligand nor metal centered. To the best of our knowledge, such behavior is unprecedented for Eu-based coordination polymers. Despite the absence of luminescence for the Eu-based polymer 6, in the near-infrared range, the other polymers 4, 10, 13, 18, 19, 26, and 28 exhibit a quite intense emission at room temperature in the near-infrared region as shown in and with more details in the Supporting Information (Figure S1).

elements.content: The intensity enhancement in near-infrared emission when using ligand L1 at room temperature, compared with the luminescent properties of compounds 13 and 28 (with Yb) and compounds 4 and 19 (with Nd), is shown in . The f–f transitions are much more distinguishable for compound 19, whereas no evident ligand-to-metal energy transfer band is observed in the series (only a weak one is observed around 350 nm), which suggest a very favorable electrostatic coordination environment for the near-infrared Ln­(III) luminescence. The edge of the emission spectrum of the Gd-based polymer 22 at 80 K seems to confirm that the excitation band around 350 nm matches well with the estimated lowest triplet state energy of the organic ligand (Figure S2). At low temperature, polymers 18, 19, and 26 showed a well-resolved spectrum in the near-infrared range but also a perceptible emission and some reabsorption bands in the visible range under UV excitation, as shown in .

elements.content: To conclude, we have explored the reactivity of ligand L toward the entire series of lanthanides for the first time. Furthermore, we have completed the series of lanthanide complexes of L1. The structures of the coordination polymers obtained with ligand L reveal that medium-strong hydrogen bonds impact the packing of polymer strands. With L1, zigzag chains form a two-dimensional sheetlike arrangement with no indication for hydrogen bonding. Moreover, the photophysical properties of the visible-light-emitting lanthanides are unexpected, showing no ligand-to-metal energy transfer, yet modified ligand emission in most cases. Europium-based polymer 6 shows unique nonemissive behavior that may be attributed to efficient energy dissipation via the ligand and polymer framework. An increased vibrational and rotational mobility in the solid state would be in agreement with the relatively large cell volume observed for solid 6 with respect to its isostructural congeners, whereas highly emissive 21 with the identical metal ion shows a significantly reduced cell volume in the solid state, which was attributed to reduced rotational mobility owing to steric congestion before. Besides structural effects, electronic grounds may add in the same vein when considering triplet excitation of the π-conjugated linker of the ligand. According to Latva’s empirical rule, for a lowest triplet state of ligand at 24 000 cm–1, there is almost no emission observable. The low-temperature measurements performed by us, for example, for the Gd-based compounds, are in support of triplet excitation of the ligand in the respective energy range.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

To conclude, we have explored the reactivity of ligand L toward the entire series of lanthanides for the first time. Furthermore, we have completed the series of lanthanide complexes of L1. The structures of the coordination polymers obtained with ligand L reveal that medium-strong hydrogen bonds impact the packing of polymer strands. With L1, zigzag chains form a two-dimensional sheetlike arrangement with no indication for hydrogen bonding. Moreover, the photophysical properties of the visible-light-emitting lanthanides are unexpected, showing no ligand-to-metal energy transfer, yet modified ligand emission in most cases. Europium-based polymer 6 shows unique nonemissive behavior that may be attributed to efficient energy dissipation via the ligand and polymer framework. An increased vibrational and rotational mobility in the solid state would be in agreement with the relatively large cell volume observed for solid 6 with respect to its isostructural congeners, whereas highly emissive 21 with the identical metal ion shows a significantly reduced cell volume in the solid state, which was attributed to reduced rotational mobility owing to steric congestion before. Besides structural effects, electronic grounds may add in the same vein when considering triplet excitation of the π-conjugated linker of the ligand. According to Latva's empirical rule, for a lowest triplet state of ligand at 24000 cm-1, there is almost no emission observable. The low-temperature measurements performed by us, for example, for the Gd-based compounds, are in support of triplet excitation of the ligand in the respective energy range.

elements.content: In the near-infrared emission range, some of the polymers, especially with ligand L1, show a strong and well-defined emission spectrum but still with no evident ligand-to-metal energy transfer, so possibly this strong near-infrared emission would be explained only by a very favorable coordination environment.

cln_elements.content:
In a microwave flask, 1.6 g (5.2 mmol) of 9,10-bis­(chloromethyl)­anthracene was placed together with 10 mL (57 mmol) of triisopropyl phosphite. The resulting mixture was heated for 1 h at 180 °C (200 W) in a microwave reactor under autogenous pressure (10 bar). Upon cooling to 20 °C, the flask was vented for 10 min to ensure degassing. The resulting yellow solid was dissolved in 50 mL of isopropanol and filtered. The isopropanol was removed at reduced pressure, and the resulting solid was washed with 100 mL of cold water and dried overnight, giving 2.8 g of yellow crystalline product with 90% yield referring to the starting material 9,10-bis­(chloromethyl)­anthracene.

Yield: 1: 150 mg, 71%; 2: 145 mg, 75%; 3: 143 mg, 74%; 4: 140 mg, 72%; 5: 155 mg, 79%; 6: 147 mg, 71%; 7: 160 mg, 77%; 8: 175 mg, 84%; 9: 173 mg, 83%; 10: 169 mg 85%; 11: 165 mg, 83%; 12: 161 mg, 77%; 13: 150 mg, 71%; 14: 152 mg, 72%; 15: 140 mg, 73%.

Synthesis of 9,10-Bis(dimethylphosphorylisopropyl) Anthracene (L)

In a microwave flask, 1.6 g (5.2 mmol) of 9,10-bis(chloromethyl)anthracene was placed together with 10 mL (57 mmol) of triisopropyl phosphite. The resulting mixture was heated for 1 h at 180 °C (200 W) in a microwave reactor under autogenous pressure (10 bar). Upon cooling to 20 °C, the flask was vented for 10 min to ensure degassing. The resulting yellow solid was dissolved in 50 mL of isopropanol and filtered. The isopropanol was removed at reduced pressure, and the resulting solid was washed with 100 mL of cold water and dried overnight, giving 2.8 g of yellow crystalline product with 90% yield referring to the starting material 9,10-bis(chloromethyl)anthracene.

Yield: 1: 150 mg, 71%; 2: 145 mg, 75%; 3: 143 mg, 74%; 4: 140 mg, 72%; 5: 155 mg, 79%; 6: 147 mg, 71%; 7: 160 mg, 77%; 8: 175 mg, 84%; 9: 173 mg, 83%; 10: 169 mg 85%; 11: 165 mg, 83%; 12: 161 mg, 77%; 13: 150 mg, 71%; 14: 152 mg, 72%; 15: 140 mg, 73%.
